noun.description: The anticipation and answering of possible objections in rhetorical speech.
The representation of a thing as existing before it actually does or did so, as in he was a dead man when he entered.
examples: the destruction of the Vendôme Column and his part in it are foreshadowed in moments of haunting prolepsis

origin: Late Middle English (as a term in rhetoric): via late Latin from Greek prolēpsis, from prolambanein anticipate, from pro before + lambanein take.
